revision.text:
{{Other ships|HMS Dominica}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image= |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=[[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|UK]] |Ship flag=[[Image:Naval Ensign of the United Kingdom.svg|60px|Royal Navy Ensign]] |Ship name=HMS ''Dominica'' |Ship ordered= |Ship builder= |Ship laid down= |Ship launched= |Ship acquired=1807 (by capture) |Ship commissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship honours= |Ship captured= |Ship fate=Foundered August 1809 |Ship status= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= |Ship type=[[schooner]] |Ship tonnage=153 [[Builder's Old Measurement|bm]] |Ship length= |Ship beam= |Ship draught= |Ship hold depth= |Ship sail plan=Schooner or brig |Ship propulsion=[[Sails]] |Ship complement= |Ship armament= 10 guns |Ship notes= }} |} '''HMS ''Dominica''''' was the French privateer schooner ''J(T?)opo L'Oeil'' (aka ''Tape à l{{'}}Oeil'' or ''Tape à l{{'}}Oeuil'' or ''Tap à l{{'}}Oeil'') that the British captured in 1807 in the Leeward Islands.<ref group=Note>British sources other than the after-action letter in the ''London Gazette'' give her name as ''Tape à L{{'}}Oeuil''.</ref> She took part in one inconclusive [[single-ship action]] before she foundered in 1809.
==Capture== On 17 October 1807 the British brig {{HMS|Superieure|1803|2}} encountered the French schooner privateer ''Jopo L'Oeil'' about 120 [[league (unit)|leagues]] east of Barbados. The sanguinary engagement between the two vessels lasted an hour and a quarter, with Captain John Buller of ''Superieure'' being killed instantly by a musket ball to the head while attempting to board the privateer early in the fight. Lieutenant John G. Bird took command and continued the fight until the privateer surrendered. She had a crew of 95 men. She was pierced for 14 guns but carried only six 18-pounders plus another one on a traveling carriage. She was 32 days out of [[Pointe-à-Pitre]] Guadeloupe and had made no captures. Bird described ''Jopo L'Oeil'' as "a remarkable fine Vessel". In the fight the British lost four men killed, including Buller, and eight men wounded; the French lost five killed and 19 wounded. The brig {{HMS|Hawke|1806|2}} was in sight during the engagement but was unable to close until after the fight was over.<ref>{{London Gazette|startpage=1746 |issue=16102|date=26 December 1807}}</ref>{{refn|A first-class share of the prize money in 1815 for the ''Tape à l{{'}}Oeil'' was [[£sd|£]]100 5[[shilling|s]] 0½[[pence|d]]; a fifth-class share, that of a seaman, was worth £1 10s 10d.<ref>{{London Gazette|startpage=656 |issue=17001|date=8 April 1815}}</ref>|group=Note}} The British took the privateer into service as HMS ''Dominica''.
==Service== The British commissioned ''Dominica'' under Lieutenant Stephen Burke.<ref name=Winfield/> At some point in 1807 Lieutenant J. Deane may have taken command.<ref name="NMM-WH-383599"/> On 3 February 1808 ''Dominica'' had an inconclusive engagement with the French privateer ''Victor'', of 18 guns.<ref name=Winfield/><ref name="NMM-WH-383599"/> In 1809 Lieutenant Charles Welch took command.<ref name=Winfield>Winfield (2008), p.365.</ref>
==Fate== ''Dominica'' foundered or capsized in a hurricane off Tortola in 1809.<ref name=Winfield/> Accounts differ as to survivors. Hepper reports that she foundered with all hands.<ref>Hepper (1994), p.130.</ref> Marx and Gossett report that there were three survivors.<ref>Marx (1975).</ref><ref>Gossett (1986), p.73.</ref> The [[National Maritime Museum]] database records that there were five survivors.<ref name="NMM-WH-383599">{{cite web|url=http://www.nmm.ac.uk/upload/pdf/Warship_Histories_Vessels_v.pdf|title=NMM, vessel ID 383599|work=Warship Histories, vol v|publisher=[[National Maritime Museum]]|accessdate=30 July 2011}}</ref>

(London: Mansell). ISBN 0-7201-1816-6 *{{cite book|last=Hepper|first=David J.|authorlink=|year=1994|title=British Warship Losses in the Age of Sail, 1650-1859|publisher=Jean Boudriot|location=Rotherfield|isbn=0-948864-30-3}} *Marx, Robert F. (1975) Shipwrecks of the Western Hemisphere, 1492-1825. (D. McKay Co.) ISBN 978-0-679-50565-5 *{{cite book |first=Rif|last=Winfield|title=British Warships in the Age of Sail 1793–1817: Design, Construction, Careers and Fates|publisher=Seaforth|year=2008|isbn=1-86176-246-1}} {{WarshipHist}}
